description: Perhaps from atone +‎ -ment as translation of Medieval Latin adūnāmentum; however, the noun is found earlier than the verb (atone); and in this light, the proper etymology is at +‎ onement.

entries.meaning: Making amends to restore a damaged relationship; expiation.
examples: When a man has been guilty of any vice, the best atonement he can make for it is, to warn others.

entries.meaning: (theology, often with capitalized initial) The reconciliation of God and mankind through the death of Jesus.
(archaic) Reconciliation; restoration of friendly relations; concord.
